value.name: About
value.content:
{{What_is_WikiRate+vision_video|float:right; margin:0px 18px}}WikiRate was born out of a simple idea: Companies improve when their impacts on the world are out in the open for everyone to see.

Lots of information exists on the social and environmental practices of corporations. But until now, it hasn’t been possible to evaluate and compare it in a meaningful way—not to mention add to it, improve it, or weigh in on its importance.

WikiRate.org is a place where everyone—individuals, advocacy groups, researchers, and companies themselves—can bring together information from a variety of sources and make it useful. Through this multitude of perspectives, a clearer picture emerges that can drive companies to respond to social and environmental issues.

WikiRate itself does not take a stand on any issues (other than advocating for greater transparency). Neither is WikiRate a gatekeeper. All kinds of data are welcome; the WikiRate community determines its worth and how it’s used.

How It Works

Check out [[How WikiRate Works]].

How to Get Involved

...as an Individual

Learn about corporate impacts and do your part to shape them.

  • Select important [[Metrics]] and [[Topics]] to be featured for you throughout the site
  • [[/new/Source|Add a Source]]; bring in material that others can use
  • Join an [[Project]]
  • Research metric values by following instructions; add new knowledge about companies
  • Create a New Metric

...as an Advocacy Group

Do more research, better, on more companies with less effort.  And then see it used widely.

  • Share and promote your research
  • Design metrics relevant to your mission 
  • Recruit volunteers to help gather data

 Soon you will be able to:

  • Dynamically rate companies by combining metrics related to your mission.
  • Advocate for use of your metrics in other' dynamic ratings

...as an Academic

Engage students and collaborators in using and improving open data.

  • Share your latest research             
  • Engage students with data and research in the classroom
  • Engage students with CSR data outside of the classroom through WikiRateX

...as a Student

Work with friends, professors, and experts on some of the most important issues of our time.

  • Join your local WikiRateX chapter if it already exists
  • Start your own if doesn't yet. We are here to help!
  • Engage with experts and important actors through efforts like company visits, panels, and direct research

WikiRateX is a global student network dedicated to pushing for corporate transparency.

 ...as a Company Representative

Celebrate what you're doing right, and learn what more you could do.  Weigh in to ensure that metrics are fair and internally useful.  Transparency will alway be rewarded on WikiRate, even when there's work to be done.

  • Share your annual CSR report in an effective, machine-readable format 
  • Provide additional source material
  • Participate in discussions on metrics
  • Respond to contributor inquiries

value.name: Advocacy
value.content:
On WikiRate you can investigate corporate practices and behaviour in areas your organisation is most concerned about. You can set up [[metrics]] which define context and ask the most important questions of companies.

Using the WikiRate.org platform allows you to freely generate transparent and high quality data which can be used for advocacy or campaigns. Data can be generated by researchers, natural community or by neighbouring interest groups.

  • Share and promote your research
  • Design metrics relevant to your mission 
  • Recruit volunteers to help gather data

 

Here are some examples of organisations which have used WikiRate for research, and the metrics which they have populated using the platform.

[[Amnesty International+contribution|Amnesty International]]

 

 

Start your own [[project]] today

 

If you have any questions, email vishal@wikirate.org to get to know a bit more about how to use the platform in this way.

value.name: Teaching
value.content:
On WikiRate you can help your students discover how company information can be used to understand social and environmental impacts. Students can use WikiRate for research based assignments in groups or as individuals to understand the most important indicators of performance for companies that are most interesting for them. 

As a professor, WikiRate allows you to engage students with public company information and help them make sense of relative company performance on major global and local issues, of interest. 

You can see some examples of student research on WikiRate by browsing previous [[Project]] on WikiRate. 

If you have any questions about how you could use WikiRate to educate students about responsive companies please contact vishal@wikirate.org.

value.name: welcome email+*html message
value.content:
Welcome to WikiRate! Becoming a member of the WikiRate community is an important step towards making companies more accountable, more transparent and ultimately better. 

Thank you!

Thank you for taking the time to join us in our mission to make companies better, together. We need an open effort to put together all the information we can find about how companies behave, to review this and decide what is worth knowing. Our aim is to use this information to build ratings (coming April 2016) of company behaviour. WikiRate and its community is uniquely positioned as a free, open and collaborative resource to achieve all of the above. 

Have a look around

WikiRate is the first place that collects ratings and metrics about companies from all around the web and from NGOs in the real world. Try browsing to a [[Company]] you are interested in, and have a look through the [[metrics]] voted as most important. You can also take a look at the projects and [[Project]] running at the moment, which you might want to get involved with. Take some time also to add some information to your profile, by clicking on your name at the top right when logged in. 

Select the topics or metrics most important to you

WikiRate is built so you can see the information you care most about. On any company page you can cast your votes for the topics you care most about by dragging them upwards (or downwards when you care less about them). These preferences will be saved so you can see content in line with your preferences around the site.

When you see a metric that you like or are interested, simply drag up the metric to cast your vote in a similar way to topics.

Dig in and be bold

There are a lot of ways for you to contribute on WikiRate. I encourage you to look further at the [[Using WikiRate]] page for all the ways you can get involved and help generate better data, better ratings and ultimately better companies. To find out more about how all this comes together visit the [[About WikiRate]] page to dig in deeper. Generally don't be scared. Try using the site as your own and other community members will help you out as you go. 

Ask for help

If you encounter any difficulties with using the site, check out http://wikirate.org/tickets - where you can let us know about any problems, or see if other people have already encountered the same problem.

Try out the [[discussion]] board to speak more openly with the community at large.  

 

We're really happy to welcome you to the community!

 

[[Vishal Kapadia]]

Executive Director

The WikiRate Project

value.name: What is WikiRate?
value.content:
WikiRate is a community effort to [[companies|make companies better]].

Companies have a huge effect on our world, and some of them behave more ethically than others. We want to measure companies' social and environmental performance so that concerned citizens can make a fair comparison between them and support companies they consider "better".  If we can make a company's impacts known in a way that affects their profitability, this will push them to behave more responsibly. 

We're gathering better information about [[companies]] and creating better [[metrics]] and [[Overview]], so anyone can compare companies, and ultimately drive companies to better themselves.

What does "better" mean? What does it mean to you? On WikiRate you can say what [[topics]] and [[metrics]] are important to you.  Your preferences will prioritize relevant content for you and will also contribute to a community vote on what matters most. Those votes will, in turn, determine what appears most prominently on the site and what information companies are most strongly urged to make public.

Like any community, we're made up of people with lots of different values. But our community is united by the idea that by making companies more understandable and more transparent, we can make them more accountable to their stakeholders: community members, employees, investors, customers, and anyone else effected by a company's choices.

 

{{+vision video|float:right; margin:0px 18px}}Better Metrics

On the right of every [[Company]] page you'll see a list of social and environmental [[Metrics]].  These aren't part of a preconceived ratings system, they're community contributions.  WikiRate provides a ratings framework where community members design, discuss, populate, and vote on [[Metrics]] to standardize measurements of a company's performance.   Metrics can include low-level indicators (like employee counts or emission measurements), high-level ratings (like a human rights score), or anything in between.

At present, all the values for these Metrics are directly entered by community members, either manually or via structured data imports.  Every directly entered value must cite a [[Source]]. Soon it will also be possible for community members to recombine the metrics to create new ones dynamically using mathematical and graphical tools. 

 

Better Overviews

On the left of every [[Company]] page you'll see a list of [[Topics]] like [[Climate Change]], [[Human Rights]], and [[Political Accountability]]. Community members write [[Overview]] connecting specific [[Companies]] to these [[Topics]]. As on most wikis, [[Overview]] are community-edited, but Wikirate has an advanced citation system to make sure the overviews are trustworthy and well-sourced. [[Overview]] must cite [[Note]], which are short, simple sourced statements about companies. [[Note]], in turn, must cite [[Sources]]. The community openly discusses and votes on both [[Note]] and [[Sources]] to determine their importance. 

[[Source]] data for both metrics and overviews can come directly from companies, from government filings, from news reports, or from any other knowledgeable party. If you know some material that should be here (a webpage, a file, or even original text), you can [[/new/Source | add a new Source]].

 

More Transparency

It's great to gather all the available data about [[Companies]].  It's even better to get [[Companies]] to gather and publish data that currently isn't available at all.

Individual WikiRate community members have a wide array opinions about how companies should behave, and therefore WikiRate as a whole seeks to take a neutral stance on how it reports behavior.  However, we take a strong stance in favor of transparency.  Without corporate transparency, we cannot gather the information we need to assess corporate behavior in any domain.

For this reason, we are in the process of implementing a [[Transparency Score|Transparency Score]] that will measure how well a company is making available the information that the WikiRate community considers most important.  In this way we hope to reward companies for transparency and give them an incentive to provide the data needed to assess their social and environmental performance.

All WikiRate [[Overview]] and [[Metrics]] will be freely available to anyone, and we will actively support their reuse.

 

Make Companies Accountable

Ultimately, the goal of WikiRate is to make companies accountable to their stakeholders: the people who live near them, buy from them, work for them, or are otherwise affected by their decisions.  The vision of WikiRate is not scolding companies, it's helping them to improve.

WikiRate.org does not impose a preconceived definition of "ethical" upon companies or other community members.  Instead, it invites its community to convey what they find "important" and bases the dynamics of the site upon what its members say.  When a member says a [[Topic]] is important (via up-voting or drag-and-drop), for example, this affects the order in which Topics are displayed.  When a member says a [[Note]] is important, this affects how a citation is visualized in an [[Overview]].  And, most relevantly, when a member says a [[Metric]] is important, that affects a company's [[Transparency Score|Transparency Score]] and nudges companies to provide more information on that Metric.

As the WikiRate community grows, we expect that its [[Overview]] and [[Metrics]] will become a more and more important source of information about companies. It will be used by consumers to determine who is worthy of their purchases. It will be used by investors to determine who is worthy of their investments. And Wikirate.org will be used by companies themselves to understand how they are performing, how they are perceived, and how they can improve both.

 

The WikiRate Community

Wikirate is for everyone who cares about how company behavior affects people and their environment.

We're not an advocacy site, but we welcome advocacy group representatives to [[/new/:signup|join]], add [[Sources]], create [[Metrics]], run data [[Project]], and otherwise participate in gathering and making sense of data related to issues that concern them.

We're not a corporate mouthpiece, but we welcome company representatives to [[/new/:signup|join]], add [[Sources]], populate [[Metrics]], and generally engage in explaining the company's impacts and the choices it makes.

We're not all experts – most of us are learning as we go.  But we are working together to break the enormous task of monitoring companies into small tasks.

If you [[/new/:signup|join our community]] (it's free!), you can add new [[sources]], edit [[Overview]], evaluate [[Note]], or fix [[fix things!|typos and other errors]]. One of the easiest ways to get started is to join a [[Project]], which is a way of focusing community attention on a specific topic or data challenge. However you choose to get involved, please know that your efforts are appreciated.  With your help, we can create a much-needed global resource for making companies clear.

 

 

[[Company|Browse Companies]] | [[Topics|Browse Topics]] | [[Project|Browse Project]]
